definitions.definition: The differential gear in an automobile , etc.
A qualitative or quantitative difference between similar or comparable things.
One of two coils of conducting wire so related to one another or to a magnet or armature common to both, that one coil produces polar action contrary to that of the other.
A form of conductor used for dividing and distributing the current to a series of electric lamps so as to maintain equal action in all.

A quantity representing an infinitesimal change in a variable , now only used as a heuristic aid except in nonstandard analysis but considered rigorous until the 20th century; a fluxion in Newtonian calculus , now usually written in Leibniz's notation as d x {\displaystyle \operatorname {d} \!x} .

{\displaystyle f(x)} ) A function giving the change in the linear approximation of f {\displaystyle f} at a point x {\displaystyle x} over a small interval Δ x {\displaystyle \Delta x} or d x {\displaystyle \operatorname {d} \!x} , the function being called the differential of f {\displaystyle f} and denoted d f ( x , Δ x ) {\displaystyle \operatorname {d} \!f(x,\Delta x)} , d f ( x ) {\displaystyle \operatorname {d} \!f(x)} , or simply d f {\displaystyle \operatorname {d} \!f} .
examples: If f ( x ) = x 2 {\displaystyle f(x)=x^{2}} , the differential of f {\displaystyle f} is the function d f ( x , Δ x ) = f ′ ( x ) Δ x = 2 x Δ x {\displaystyle \operatorname {d} \!f(x,\Delta x)=f'(x)\Delta x=2x\Delta x} .

subdefinitions.definition: Any of several generalizations of this concept to functions of several variables or to higher orders : the partial differential , total differential , Gateaux differential , etc.

labels: of a univariate differentiable function f ( x
definitions.label_groups: calculus , of a univariate differentiable function f ( x

definitions.definition: The Jacobian matrix of a function of several variables.

The pushforward or total derivative of ϕ {\displaystyle \phi } : a linear map from the tangent space at a point x {\displaystyle x} in ϕ {\displaystyle \phi } 's domain to the tangent space at ϕ ( x ) {\displaystyle \phi (x)} which is, in a technical sense, the best linear approximation of ϕ {\displaystyle \phi } at x {\displaystyle x} ; denoted d ϕ x {\displaystyle \operatorname {d} \!\phi _{x}} .
labels: of a smooth map ϕ {\displaystyle \phi } between smooth manifolds
definitions.label_groups: differential geometry , of a smooth map ϕ {\displaystyle \phi } between smooth manifolds

definitions.definition: Any of several generalizations of the concept(s) above: e.g. the Kähler differential in the setting of schemes , the quadratic differential in the theory of Riemann surfaces , etc.

main_definition: The differential gear in an automobile , etc.
secondary_definitions: A qualitative or quantitative difference between similar or comparable things.
One of two coils of conducting wire so related to one another or to a magnet or armature common to both, that one coil produces polar action contrary to that of the other.
A form of conductor used for dividing and distributing the current to a series of electric lamps so as to maintain equal action in all.

( calculus ) A quantity representing an infinitesimal change in a variable , now only used as a heuristic aid except in nonstandard analysis but considered rigorous until the 20th century; a fluxion in Newtonian calculus , now usually written in Leibniz's notation as d x {\displaystyle \operatorname {d} \!x} .

( calculus , of a univariate differentiable function f ( x ) {\displaystyle f(x)} ) A function giving the change in the linear approximation of f {\displaystyle f} at a point x {\displaystyle x} over a small interval Δ x {\displaystyle \Delta x} or d x {\displaystyle \operatorname {d} \!x} , the function being called the differential of f {\displaystyle f} and denoted d f ( x , Δ x ) {\displaystyle \operatorname {d} \!f(x,\Delta x)} , d f ( x ) {\displaystyle \operatorname {d} \!f(x)} , or simply d f {\displaystyle \operatorname {d} \!f} .
( multivariable calculus ) The Jacobian matrix of a function of several variables.

( differential geometry , of a smooth map ϕ {\displaystyle \phi } between smooth manifolds ) The pushforward or total derivative of ϕ {\displaystyle \phi } : a linear map from the tangent space at a point x {\displaystyle x} in ϕ {\displaystyle \phi } 's domain to the tangent space at ϕ ( x ) {\displaystyle \phi (x)} which is, in a technical sense, the best linear approximation of ϕ {\displaystyle \phi } at x {\displaystyle x} ; denoted d ϕ x {\displaystyle \operatorname {d} \!\phi _{x}} .
( mathematics ) Any of several generalizations of the concept(s) above: e.g. the Kähler differential in the setting of schemes , the quadratic differential in the theory of Riemann surfaces , etc.
